timeline.bodyText: Actually, now that I think of it, I think that this block was meant to test that that the truststore is used by default. With the change it won't be doing that as the truststore is specific to the rest client
timeline.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Sounds like a test smell to me :)
replies.author: gastaldi

replies.bodyText: Maybe... But what other way do you have of testing that the truststore works in native mode?
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Well, setting the truststore specifically in the TestResource class for the rest client works in native, maybe that's how we should do it to keep tests isolated
replies.author: gastaldi

replies.bodyText: The thing is that for native, truststore isn't settable at runtime IIRC
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I am still against this change. The rest looks real good
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I am probably missing something, but how do you set the default trust store in this test? I don't see that being done in the existing test, can you point me to where that is set?
replies.author: gastaldi

replies.bodyText: I'll take a closer look tomorrow
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
What I said above is indeed why it was done this way. And it works because of: 
  
    
      quarkus/integration-tests/rest-client/pom.xml
    
    
         Line 105
      in
      22c529e
    
    
    
    

        
          
           <javax.net.ssl.trustStore>${self-signed.trust-store}</javax.net.ssl.trustStore> 
        
    
  


So I really think this part of the PR should be reverted, otherwise we have no way of testing the default trust-store handling in native image
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText:
@geoand this wasn't changed, the system properties are still set when the test runs and the specified trust-store is still loaded as the default in both tests.
Note that there isn't a QuarkusTestResourceLifecycleManager associated with the ExternalSelfSignedTestCase, so the self-signed.trust-store is used only in the javax.net.ssl.trustStore property
replies.author: gastaldi

replies.bodyText: Yeah, but unless I am misreading the PR, now there is nowhere where the default trust-store is exercised. This is what the existing code is meant to do
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: I see, but is this the right place to test this feature? I mean, this is not related to the rest-client integration, right?
replies.author: gastaldi

replies.bodyText:
Yes and no.
I added it here because this came about when I fixed the SSL handling a little while a back (it broke when we moved to 19.3).
And unless we have this sort of test, it can easily break again.
Sure there are perhaps better places to put it, but I don't really see a lot of value in moving it
replies.author: geoand

replies.bodyText: Cool, I'm convinced now. Thanks for the explanation 😉
replies.author: gastaldi

timeline.bodyText: If it's exposed to the user and not some implementation detail, it should be at the root, not in the runtime package.
